awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: Volumetric Light-Assisted Manufacturing of Dental Implants and Tissue Scaffolds
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of a biomanufacturing tool for dental products. To date, most dental implants have been made by selective application of a single starting material by making a specific mold for each case. The main limitations of such approaches are low fabrication speeds, significant labor costs, and lack of stability in materials that are produced. It is crucial to achieve a high fabricate rate and stable constructs without limiting the desired function of the implant or tissue scaffold. An ideal dental implant fabrication method should make molds within minutes.  Modern 3D printing techniques and proper material selection enable this technology to rebuild portions of lost tissue.

This I-Corps project is based on the development of a customizable, light-assisted, 3D printing platform that allows for quick fabrication of polymer-based inks and hydrogels.  The technology will be used to fabricate stable and functional (dental) implants. Such polymeric inks are based on photoresponsive molecules in the material. This technology will use ultraviolet (UV) crosslinking of methacrylate groups in conventional hydrogels or polymer precursors for long-term stability of the selected implant. Advantages of this technology include: a modular chamber for multi-component biomaterials; very rapid fabrication of implants, scaffolds, and surgical tools; a significant level of control creation, and a low-cost product.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

inst.inst_street_address: 323 DR MARTIN LUTHER KING JR BLVD

perf_inst.perf_str_addr: 323 DR MARTIN LUTHER KING JR BLVD

por.por_cntn:
Most implants have been made by selective application of a single precursor or polymeric material and making a specific mold for each case. The main limitations of such approaches are low fabrication speeds, significant labor costs, and lack of stability in composite materials. It is crucial to achieve a high fabrication rate and good stable constructs without limiting the desired function of the implant or tissue scaffold. In the case of dental implants, this has impacted the current treatments regarding the number of treatments and material selection. An ideal fabrication method should rapidly make molds within minutes and form the structure to prevent dislodgement and ingestion of the material. To overcome these limitations, modern 3D printing techniques and proper material selection can enable us to rebuild the resected portion of lost tissue. We propose that by designing a customizable printing platform, we will fabricate stable and functional (dental) implants. Such polymeric inks will work based on a photo-responsive molecule in the material. In this peoject, we performed market analysis and customer discovery to identify the key problems in the market. Our overarching goal was to translate this biomanufacturing tool into various clinics in the United States.

The team has completed two NSF I-Corps programs: a Site Program at I-Corps Hub: Northeast Region (Grant # 2048602) and the National Program (Fall Cohort 2022) in collaboration with Rice University (Award 234496, Team 2830). We have interviewed ~135 potential customers (oral surgeons, orthodontists, prosthodontists and endodontists, dental facility workers, managers of clinical dentists, and director of digital dentistry), several potential partners, and competitors. The results of the interviews highlighted the need to generate prosthodontic products such as crowns and temporary implants in an easy and simple process step. From our I-Corps Programs, we learned about the process of dental procedures and associated problems.  In the dental field, it was determined that potential customers would include dental practitioners, mainly prosthodontists. Using our volumetric light-based printer, prosthodontic products can be quickly made with affordable material disposal. There is also a clear need for in-office manufacturing of dental products.  We would make the custom printer and find well-established biomaterial products that fit our device. This would enable us to expand our technology to another dental product. 

Our business statement focused on the ability of our product to print dental products in a single process instead of the multiple processes used at present, which is time-consuming and expensive. The capacity to change the physical properties of the dental materials (biomaterials) used for dental printing enables easy, precise, and fast fabrication of various restorative dental products for short (e.g., soft dental products) and long-term placement. These product values were questioned by various potential customers, ranging from prosthodontists to dental faculty in the Northeast area. The questions were more open-ended to get responses that may provide some insights into the problems and pain points that the customers have. Most answers were analyzed and tabulated to extract the key values for such products. In summary, a combination of real-time, user-friendly, economical fabrication technology and economical material packaging was found to be critical for dental practitioners and prosthodontists to make temporary molds for restorative treatments.

 


Last Modified: 12/31/2023
Modified by: Amir K Miri
